Enhanced demethylation of aromatic ether to phenol over NiAl hydrotalcite-derived nickel sulfide catalyst Na Ji Conceptualization Methodology Resources Project administration Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Alazar Alemayehu Methodology Investigation Writing – review & editing Hanyang Li Methodology Poknam Ri Methodology Xinyong Diao Conceptualization Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Biomass/Wastes Utilization, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, PR China School of Environmental Science and Engineering Tianjin Key Laboratory of Biomass/Wastes Utilization Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 PR China School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Biomass/Wastes Utilization, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The production of phenol from lignin or its model compounds, instead of cumene oxidation is very interesting from the viewpoint of sustainability and economics. The selective demethylation of anisole was an efficient but challenging route to produce phenol. In this work, we demonstrated the fabrication of nickel sulfide (Ni9S8+NixS6) nanoparticles on Al2O3 matrix by a facile in situ sulfidation of NiAl hydrotalcite and announced that nickel sulfide can serve as efficient active site for the demethylation of anisole for the first time. The as-designed 4Ni1Al-S catalyst exhibited a hierarchical morphology with a high particle density and high dispersion, affording a 95.6% yield of phenol in the demethylation of anisole under relative milder reaction temperature (270 °C) when compared to the reported state-of-the-art results. By comprehensive characterizations and experiments, we inferred that the nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure exhibited stronger metal-support interaction than that obtained from the impregnation method, which not only benefits the uniform dispersion of active nickel sulfide but also results in the electronic transfer from Ni center to Al2O3 support. As a consequence, enhanced demethylation activity was achieved on 4Ni1Al-S in comparison to Ni-S/Al2O3-IM. Graphical Abstract Description: The nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure exhibited stronger metal-support interaction than that obtained from the impregnation method, which presented enhanced demethylation activity with 90.8% yield of phenol in anisole conversion. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Anisole Demethylation Phenol Hydrotalcite Nickel sulfide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Phenol is the key component of resin, bisphenol A, and prolactam, and its world consumption is up to 7 million tons per year [1]. For instance, phenol is mainly provided from fossil resources via multiple catalytic step (Scheme 1a), and the industrial production of phenol focused on the synthetic method of cumene oxidation, benzene oxidation, toluene chlorination, and etc [2,3]. In this case, arene monomer, which was regarded as one of the most important downstream products in the petrochemical industry [3,4], was used as raw material to synthesize phenol. However, it is necessary to seed more environmentally friendly and renewable natural energy to replace the current industrial route. Fortunately, lignin is the only renewable carbon source containing rich aromatic structures and high oxygen content in nature, which made it possess great potential to produce phenol or alkyl-phenol. Considering the complex structure of raw lignin, rarely publications achieved direct production of phenol from raw lignin. Wang et al. [2] proposed a “cutting tail” methodology to produce phenol with 13 wt. % yield from poplar lignin via an oxidation-hydrogenation route. In most case, model compounds derived from lignin depolymerization with representative block construction was usually applied for laboratory research [5,6]. As exhibited in Scheme 1b, methoxyl (-OCH3) and hydroxyl (-OH) are the most abundant functional groups in lignin side chain, guaiacol (both methoxyl and hydroxyl group) and anisole (single methoxyl group) were regarded as typical model compounds to produce phenol via catalytic hydrogenation. In recent years, many catalysts have been studied for guaiacol or anisole conversion under catalytic hydrotreatment [7,8]. It is well accepted that the catalytic ability of H2 activation and oxygenate activation are indispensable in the lignin model compounds hydrotreatment reaction [9]. Therefore, catalysts including noble metals, transition metals, transition metal metallics (oxides, sulfides, carbides, nitrides, phosphide), etc were adopted for the production of phenol from guaiacol or anisole [10–12]. Among them, metal catalysts, metal nitrides and phosphides which could easily absorb and activate hydrogen have been proposed as excellent hydrogenation catalysts [13]. However, these catalysts prefer parallel adsorption to vertical adsorption of the benzene ring, and always lead to an over-hydrogenation of the benzene rings and result in cycloalkanes or cyclohexanols as the final product [14–17]. Compared to the above-mentioned catalysts, metal oxides, sulfides and carbides were proved to be superior catalysts for the production of aromatic products, ascribe to the preferentially vertical adsorption of the OCH3 and -OH groups in the benzene side chain [4]. For the guaiacol route, the rational design of catalysts that could selectively cleave the CAr-OCH3 bond while restraining the cleavage of CAr-OH bond and the hydrogenation of the benzene ring was crucial to the production of phenol. Ma et al. [18] reported an α-MoC1-x/AC catalyst with remarkable activity in the selective deoxygenation of guaiacol to phenol and substituted mono-phenols. Our previous work demonstrated a novel Mo-Sn bimetallic oxide catalyst which could convert guaiacol to phenol with 92.5% yield, ascribed to the enhanced demethoxylation and demethylation ability [19]. Different from the guaiacol route, the anisole route focus on the selective cleavage of the CArO-CH3 bond, as illustrated in Scheme 1 b. The direct cleavage of the CAr-OCH3 bond or the further removal of -OH group would result in the production of benzene [20–22]. To our knowledge, the production of phenol from anisole via selective demethylation is a highly challenging task, in which the current phenol yield was low than 70% (Table S1) [23,24]. Theoretically, anisole obtains two different C-O bonds with BDEs of 90.7 kcal mol−1 and 54.2 kcal mol−1 for CAr-OCH3, and CArO-CH3, respectively. The selective cleavage of the CArO-CH3 bond requires relatively moderate hydrogenolysis ability compared to that of the CAr-OCH3 bond [25]. Based on this, our previous work reported a H4Nb2O7 modified MoS2 catalyst with weakened demethoxylation ability and enhanced demethylation ability to give a 95.7% yield of phenol from anisole, which demonstrated the highest phenol yield at the hither compared to with other heterogeneous catalysts in the previous studies [26]. Besides MoS2-based sulfides, other sulfides such as iron and cobalt sulfides also exhibit unique C-O bond cleave capacity. For example, FeS2/AC catalyst could selectivity cleave the α-O bond in dibenzyl ether and gave a toluene yield up to 100% [27]. Commercial CoS2 catalyst could catalyze the cleavage of methylene C−C bonds as well as C-O bonds [28]. Inspired by these results, we proposed that the nickel sulfide species may be served as an efficient active site for the demethylation of anisole into phenol, and this has not been announced til now. To achieve the high particle density and high dispersion of nickel sulfide, here we fabricated nickel sulfide nanoparticles supported on Al2O3 matrix (NiAl-S) by a facile in situ sulfidation of NiAl layered double hydroxide (NiAl-LDH), and the catalytic performances toward conversion of anisole were studied in detail. The optimization of reaction conditions including reaction temperature, H2 pressure, reaction time, catalyst dosage, and Ni/Al molar ratio was primarily carried out. Then the catalytic structure-activity relationship was investigated based on comprehensive characterizations and experiments, and the reaction pathway was also proposed. Finally, the stability of the catalyst was also investigated. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, urea, and NH4F were provided by Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. Anisole, p-anisole, c-anisole, m-anisole, phenol, p-cresol, c-cresol, m-cresol, dodecane, benzene, cyclohexane, n-hexane, toluene, n-decane, methyl cyclohexane, cyclohexanol, cyclohexanone, cyclohexane, and methylcyclopentane were bought from Aladdin. The above-mentioned chemicals were directly used without any pretreatments. Al2O3 support was purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd, and it was dried at 400°C in a N2 flow for 4 h before use. The N2, H2S/H2 and N2/H2 gas were purchased from Tianjin Boliming Technology Co, Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis NiAl-LDH precursors with varied Ni/Al molar ratio were synthesized by hydrothermal method. Generally, m mol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, n mol Al(NO3)3·9H2O, 0.5 mol urea, and 0.2 mol NH4F were dissolved in 120 mL of deionized water (m+n= 0.075). The resulting solution was aged in a sealed-Teflon autoclave at 110°C for 20 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained NiAl-LDH precipitate was thoroughly washed with distilled water, and then dried at 60°C oven overnight. After the calcination at 550°C for 4 h (NiAl-O) and further sulfidation at 400°C for 4 h in the flow of H2S/H2 (60 ml/min, Vol(H2S) = 10 %), the corresponding sample was named as xNiyAl-S, where x/y represented the Ni/Al molar ratio. For comparison, NiAl-H was obtained by reduction of NiAl-O at 450°C for 4 h in the flow of N2/H2 (100 ml/min, Vol(H2) = 50 %), and Ni-S/Al2O3-IM was prepared by traditional impregnation method with the Ni loading of 50 wt.% based on the procedure reported by Shafaghat et al. [29]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns data were attained on D8-focus powder crystallography with an X-ray generator 18kV, focus size 0.1*10 mm, and 200 mA Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54056 Å). The scanning angle was between 10° to 80° with a scanning speed of 8o/min. X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) analysis was applied via ultra-high vacuum scanning microprobe using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer. Binding energies were determined with adventitious carbon (C 1s at 284.6 eV) as the reference. SEM images were taken with a JSM-7800F thermal field emission scanning electron microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed using a JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope operated at 200 kV. The Brunauer-Emmett- Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific area of the mesoporous materials with a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 surface area and porosity analyzer. CO pulse chemisorption was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 automatic analyzer, and all the samples were pretreated at 300°C for 1 h in the Ar atmosphere before test. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was conducted on a Thermo 7000 series analyzer to determine the bulk composition of the samples. The samples were completely dissolved by chloroazotic acid with the microwave assistant before test. Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (Py-IR) was employed on a Tensor27 (Bruker, Germany) spectrophotometer in the wavenumber range of 1400-1700 cm−1, and the evacuation was performed at 150°C to measure the IR spectra. 2.4 Catalyst test The catalytic conversion of anisole was performed in a 50 mL AB50-C276 reactor (Shanghai LABE Instrument Co., Ltd). In a typical experiment, 20 mL solvent with 2.5 mmol anisole and 2.5 mmol dodecane (internal standard), and a certain amount of as-prepared catalyst were charged into the reactor. Then the reactor was pressured with a certain initial pressure of H2 at ambient temperature and stirred with 1000 rpm/min. The reaction was conducted at a certain temperature. After the reaction, the products were directly identified by GC-MS (Agilent 6890A-5975C) and quantified by GC (SP-7890) using a flame ionization detector (FID) with a 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm WondaCap WAX capillary column. The anisole conversion and the yield and selectivity of each product were calculated according to Eq. (1), Eq. (2) and Eq. (3), respectively. (eq 1) Conversion ( % ) = 1 − number of moles of residual anisole in product ) number of moles of initial anisole × 100 % (eq 2) Product yield ( A , % ) = number of moles of product A number of moles of initial anisole × 100 % (eq 3) Product selectivity ( A , % ) = number of moles of product A number of moles of reacted anisole × 100 The intrinsic reaction rate of anisole conversion and phenol formation was calculated assuming a pseudo-first-order reaction as below, with the conversion < 50%. (eq 4) Ln ( 1 − C anisole or Y phenol ) = − kt where k is the pseudo-first-order rate constant (h−1), Canisole is the conversion of anisole, Yphenol is the yield of phenol, and t is the reaction time (h). 2.4 Hot filtration test In the catalyst test reaction with the following conditions: 20 mL MYCH (methylcyclohexane) solvent with 2.5 mmol anisole and 2.5 mmol dodecane, 54 mg fresh 4Ni1Al-S catalyst, initial H2 pressure 2 MPa, and reaction temperature 270 °C, the hot filtration test is applied by filtering the reaction mixture through a pre-heated Celite pad after the reaction for 1 h. Then the filtrate was quantified by GC to obtain the anisole conversion. The filtrate was further charged into the reactor and continued to react for 1 h under the same conditions. Finally, the products were analyzed by GC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization xNiyAl-S catalysts were prepared by calcination of flower-like NiAl-LDH with different Ni/Al molar ratio, followed by sulfidation under H2/H2S atmosphere (Fig. 1 a). After the calcination and sulfidation process, highly dispersed nickel sulfide NPs were anchored on Al2O3 matrix based on the structural topotactic transformation of LDH [30,31]. The Ni content in xNiyAl-S can be facilely controlled by tuning the Ni/Al molar ratio of the parent NiAl-LDH (Table 1 ). The XRD pattern of 4Ni1Al-LDH precursor (Fig. 2 a) shows characteristic reflections at 2θ =11.68°, 23.44°, and 35.10°, which can be indexed to (003), (006), and (012) of an LDH phase (PDF#48-0594), respectively. SEM image (Fig. S1) displays that the as-synthesized hierarchical NiAl-LDH is composed of numerous frizzy nanoflakes intercrossing with each other. After the calcination, only NiO phase (PDF#47-1049) was observed in the 4Ni1Al-O sample. No diffraction peaks of spinel NiAl2O4 can be found, suggesting that Ni existed as separated NiO species on the Al2O3 surface. Further reduction process resulted in the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni (PDF#04-0850). As shown in Fig. 2c, the 4Ni1Al-S catalyst displayed both sharp diffraction peaks of Ni9S8 (PDF# 22-1193) and NixS6 (6<x<7) (PDF# 51-0717), whereas the Ni-S/Al2O3-IM catalyst presented sharp diffraction peaks of Ni9S8 and week signal of NixS6. With the raise of Ni/Al molar ratio in xNiyAl-S, it can be seen that the diffraction peak intensity of Ni9S8 phase slightly enhanced (Fig. 2b) and that of NixS6 phase also varied. SEM images in Fig. 1b-d and Fig. S2 show that the morphology of the resulting samples (2Ni1Al-S, 4Ni1Al-S, 7Ni1Al-S,) remain the original hierarchical morphology of NiAl-LDH precursor. TEM and HRTEM (Fig. 1e and Fig. S3a) images further reveal the particular structure of the xNiyAl-S. It is observed that nickel sulfide nanoparticles are highly dispersed within Al2O3 matrix with a mean size of 18.2 nm in 4Ni1Al-S and 22.9 nm in 7Ni1Al-S (Table 1). In addition, the HRTEM images in Fig. 1f and Fig. S3b reveal the lattice fringes of corresponding Ni9S8 (d222 = 0.28 nm). These are in good accordance with the XRD result. More importantly, no obvious sintering/aggregation is found owing to the anchoring effect from the support, which results in high content as well as highly dispersed nickel sulfide nanoparticles on the Al2O3 surface. The nitrogen physisorption isotherms of the xNiyAl-S samples with different Ni/Al molar ratios corresponded to type IV isotherms, which are characteristic of mesoporous adsorbents (Fig. S4). Summarized in Table 1 are the textural properties of the xNiyAl-S samples. It can be seen that the SBET decreased whereas the pore volume and diameter increased with the raise of Ni content in xNiyAl-S. Moreover, the particle size determined via TEM also increased along with the rise of Ni content. These indicate that the Ni/Al ratio had a significant influence on the morphology and particle size of the catalysts. The CO pulse adsorption experiment was employed to examine the valid dispersion of Ni species. For xNiyAl-S samples, the CO uptake increased along with the raise of Ni content, suggesting that the nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure renders good dispersion even in high Ni content. For the 4Ni1Al-S and Ni-S/Al2O3-IM with similar Ni content, the 4Ni1Al-S possessed significantly higher CO uptake, indicating a better dispersion of nickel sulfide on Al2O3 support in 4Ni1Al-S catalyst. XPS measurements were carried out to give information on the electronic structure of as-prepared catalysts. Fig. 3 a shows the Ni 2p XPS results. For the Ni-S/Al2O3-IM catalyst, the bands centered at 853.1 and 870.3 eV can be attributed to the spine-orbit characteristics of Ni2+, and those at 856.2 and 874.1 eV are associated with the spine-orbit characteristics of Ni3+, respectively, implying the Ni2+ and Ni3+ state in Ni9S8 phase [32–34]. However, for the 4Ni1Al-S catalysts, the absence of the Ni2+ state and the positive shift of the binding energy value of Ni3+ when compared with the standard binding energy in pure Ni9S8 (856.3 eV) [32] and the above Ni-S/Al2O3-IM (856.2 eV) sample implied electronic transfer from Ni to Al2O3 support [17]. It seemed that the nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure exhibited stronger metal-support interaction than that obtained from the impregnation method [35]. This may explain the phase difference of nickel sulfide in 4Ni1Al-S and Ni-S/Al2O3-IM catalysts, in which more NixS6 was formed in xNiyAl-S catalysts. Fig. 3b shows the S 2p XPS results. The binging energy at 162.2 eV suggests that the S element exists as S2−, and the peaks 169.0 eV can be assigned to the inevitable oxidation of S into SOx. The two peaks at 532.1 eV and 533.2 eV in Fig. 3c indicate the presence of lattice oxygen (OL) and surface oxygen vacancy (OV) in Al2O3 phase, respectively [19]. It can be seen that no signal of OV was detected in Ni-S/Al2O3-IM while appearing in 4Ni1Al-S catalysts, indicating that the electronic transfer from Ni to Al2O3 support resulting the formation of more OV. In most cases, the OV in Al2O3 could act as Lewis acid sites. We further performed Py-FTIR to analyze the acidic character of the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 3 d. The pure Al2O3 support displays peaks of the pyridine-adsorbed Lewis acid sites at 1450 and 1590 cm−1. The 4Ni1Al-S showed slightly higher Lewis acidity than Ni-S/Al2O3-IM agrees well with the XPS analysis that more Ov was formed. Generally, compared with Ni-S/Al2O3-IM catalyst, the LDH-derived 4Ni1Al-S exhibited stronger metal-support interaction, which resulted in the formation of more NixS6 phase and more oxygen vacancy in Al2O3 surface. Besides, the Ni/Al molar ratio in xNiyAl-S also influences the electronic structure. The binding energy value of Ni3+ in different xNiyAl-S catalysts remains a significant positive shift, indicating the strong metal-support interaction. However, the content of OV significantly reduced with the raise of Ni/Al molar ratio and even no signal of OV can be observed in 7Ni1Al-S. This probably due to the the occupation of more nickel sulfide nanoparticles on Al2O3 suface, and more serious surface oxidation of S into SOx may also occupy the Al2O3 suface according to S 2p spectra in Fig. 3 b. In summary, here we successfully synthesized NiAl-S catalysts with high content and highly dispersed Ni9S8+NixS6 nanoparticles anchored on Al2O3 matrix by a facile in situ sulfidation of NiAl hydrotalcite. The characterizations demonstrated that the nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure exhibited stronger metal-support interaction than that obtained from the impregnation method, which not only benefits the uniform dispersion of active nickel sulfide but also results in the electronic transfer from Ni center to Al2O3 support. Moreover, the morphology, Ni content, particle size and electronic structure of the xNiyAl-S catalysts varied along with the change of Ni/Al molar ratio. 3.2 Catalyst screening and optimization of reaction condition The catalytic activities of the prepared materials were tested using the demethylation of lignin model anisole as a model reaction. The xNiyAl-S catalysts with different Ni/Al molar ratio were firstly evaluated to screen the optimized catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 4 a and Table S2, all the xNiyAl-S catalysts were active for the demethylation of anisole with the anisole conversion >90% and phenol yield >80% under the reaction condition of 270 °C at 2 MPa H2 for 3 h. Among them, Ni9S8-Al2O3-4/1 attained the highest phenol yield of 90.8%, which was selected as the optimized catalyst for further study. Optimization of the reaction conditions showed that the catalytic activity and the selectivity of the products highly depended on the reaction temperature and initial H2 pressure (Table S3, 4, 5). As illustrated in Fig. 4b, when the initial H2 pressure was 5 MPa, not only the corresponding conversion of anisole but also the yield of phenol increased sharply with the increasing reaction temperature from 250 to 300 °C. This suggests that Ni9S8-Al2O3 catalyzed CArO-CH3 bond cleavage is a thermodynamically controlled reaction. Temperature lower than 270 °C could only afford a phenol yield less than 50.0%. Taking economy and energy consumption into consideration, we further investigated the effect of initial H2 pressure at 270 °C. Interestingly, the initial H2 pressure significantly influenced the reaction rate. The presence of 2.0 MPa H2 remarkably improved the anisole conversion and phenol yield to 95.1% and 90.8% at 270 °C, respectively. Higher H2 pressure (≥ 3 MPa) led to a continuous decline both in anisole conversion and phenol selectivity, which was probably caused by the inhibition of substrate adsorption due to the high coverage of hydrogen on the catalyst surface [36] . The optimization of reaction temperature under 2 MPa H2 demonstrated that 270 °C was the suitable reaction temperature as higher temperature did not show clear difference in phenol yield. The effect of substrate/catalyst mass ratio on the conversion efficiency was also explored. As shown in Fig. 4c, increasing the catalyst dosage gradually enhanced phenol yield from 90.8% to 96.9% whilst the phenol selectivity remained around 96.0%, further suggesting that this Ni9S8-Al2O3-4/1 exhibited excellent activity and selectivity in the demethylation of anisole to phenol. The reaction performance also depends heavily on the nature of the solvent. As presented in Fig. 4d, different solvents mainly affected the conversion rate of anisole whereas showed little influence on phenol selectivity, and methylcyclohexane proved to be superior solvent in demethylation of anisole to phenol. In summary, the optimized Ni9S8-Al2O3-4/1 catalyst could reach >90% phenol yield under 270°C, 3 h and 2 MPa in methylcyclohexane solvent with the mass ratio of catalyst/guaiacol = 1/5. 3.3 Analysis of catalytic structure-activity relationship Control experiments and kinetic studies were further performed to get insight into the catalytic structure-activity relationship. Firstly, we compared the catalytic performance of no catalyst, pure Al2O3, Ni-S/Al2O3-IM, 4Ni1Al-H, and 4Ni1Al-S under optimized conditions. As displayed in Fig. 5 a, the blank run gave essentially no activity in this system. When Al2O3 was used as the catalyst, a 28.0% conversion of anisole into phenol (yield, 20.0%) was reached, and it is inferred that the activity of the Al2O3 sample is mainly derived from its surface Lewis acid sites [37–39]. For 4Ni1Al-H catalyst with the formation of Ni0 nanoparticles on Al2O3 matrix, the guaiacol conversion reached 99.8% and the main products were cyclohexane (yield, 87.0%) and methylcyclopentane (yield, 10.5%), which was in accordance with the previous reports on Ni-based metal catalyst [15,40,41]. In the case of Ni-S/Al2O3-IM catalyst, a 60.0% anisole conversion with 53.7% phenol yield was reached, demonstrating that Ni9S8+NixS6 can serve as excellent active species for the selective demethylation of anisole into phenol. However, the reaction rate was not satisfied. For 4Ni1Al-S catalysts, phenol could be obtained at the yield of 90.8% with the anisole conversion of 95.1%, in which the demethylation rate was significantly higher than Ni-S/Al2O3-IM. Considerating the structure difference between Ni-S/Al2O3-IM and 4Ni1Al-S, we inferred that it is the strong metal-support interaction that promotes the demethylation of anisole to generate phenol. Notably, it is hard to identify the role of single Ni9S8 and NixS6, since we failed to synthesize Ni9S8/Al2O3 and NixS6/Al2O3 samples. As Ni/Al molar ratio influenced the structure-property as well as catalytic performance, we further carried out the kinetic studies over xNiyAl-S catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 5 b. In the initial reaction, the anisole conversion rate over 2Ni1Al-S and 4Ni1Al-S was almost the same, whereas decreased over 7Ni1Al-S. Moreover, the phenol formation rate over 4Ni1Al-S was much higher than that of 2Ni1Al-S and 7Ni1Al-S. According to the characterization results, the content of the active nickel sulfide were enlarged with the increase of Ni/Al molar ratio in xNiyAl-S, which would favor the demethylation. However, the decreased surface area and Ov content, and increased particle size would also prejudice the catalytic reaction. As a consequence, the catalytic performance of the xNiyAl-S catalysts presented volcanic curve, and the appropriate Ni/Al molar ratio is 4/1 which presented the maximum demethylation activity and agrees well with the result in Fig. 4 a. Based on the above discussion, we proposed the catalytic cycles over different catalysts, as illustrated in Scheme 2 . It is widely accepted that H2 dissociation and oxygenate activation ability are essential for the C-O hydrogenolysis reaction, and the adsorption model determines the reaction route [42]. For single Al2O3 support (Scheme 2 a), its surface Ov could serve as Lewis acid site to partly catalyze the demethylation of anisole into phenol with relative low yield. For NiAl-H catalysts (Scheme 2 b), the surface Ni0 species could easily adsorb and activate the H2, and the parallel adsorption of benzene ring over Ni0 site would lead to the saturation of benzene ring, and further hydrogenolysis to generate cyclohexane as final product. For Ni-S/Al2O3-IM catalyst (Scheme 2 c), the loading of nickel sulfide could significantly promote the demethylation. It is generally acknowledged that the edges of metal sulfide play an important role in the catalysis process for the high activity of exposed atoms on the edge [43]. In our case, we proposed that it is also the edge site in nickel sulfides that act as active center to catalyze the H2 dissociation, and further promote the reaction between dissociated hydrogen and CArO-CH3 bond to generate phenol as the final product. More importantly, different from the Ni° center, it can also infer that vertical adsorption of CAr-OCH3 over nickel sulfide sites was dominated. As for 4Ni1Al-S catalyst, the nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure exhibited stronger metal-support interaction than that obtained from the impregnation method, which not only benefits the uniform dispersion of active nickel sulfide but also results in the electronic transfer from Ni center to Al2O3 support. Uniform dispersion usually facilitates the exposure of surface active center [39], and the electronic transfer from Ni center to Al2O3 support would allow the Ni center to become electron-poor centers and consequently strengthen their affinity for binding electron-donating groups such as CArO-CH3 [17,19,20]. Therefore, the highly exposed electron-poor Ni centers over 4Ni1Al-S could achieve enhanced demethylation activity (Scheme 2 d). The performance of 4Ni1Al-S catalyst for demethylation of anisole to phenol and benzene was also compared with the previously reported literature (Fig. 5c). It can be seen that the formation of benzene with high yield (>80%) can be achieved in CoMoS or Fe2P catalysts [44,45], whereas the formation of phenol was low than 70% (Table S1). The 90.8% yield of phenol over the 4Ni1Al-S catalyst in this work are much better than that of the previously reported catalysts. And the optimal reaction condition in this catalyst system (270 °C, 2 MPa H2, and 3 h) especially for reaction temperature is much milder than that in most research (higher than 320 °C). Therefore, the 4Ni1Al-S catalyst has an excellent catalytic performance in the process of demethylation of anisole to phenol. 3.4 Elucidation of reaction pathway In order to explore the reaction pathway of 4Ni1Al-S-catalyzed demethylation of anisole, we tracked and analyzed the distribution of products at different reaction times (Fig. 6 a). At 270°C and 2 MPa H2, anisole was rapidly converted to phenol by demethylation of CArO-CH3 in 3 h with the anisole conversion of 95.1%. The kinetic study displayed in Fig. 5b also supports that it is the demethylation of CArO-CH3 dominates the reaction in the initial stage. By-products were detected as benzene, cyclohexanol, cyclohexanone, and cyclohexane. Traced benzene (lower than 0.1%) was observed throughout the whole reaction. When using phenol as reactant, no benzene was generated (Fig. 6b). Thus we inferred that the traced benzene was formed by the direct demethoxylation of anisole, whereas no dihydroxylation of phenol could happen. The cyclohexanone was formed in the initial 2 h and then disappeared with the reaction time prolonged. When using cyclohexanone as reactant, it was almost completely converted into cyclohexanol and cyclohexane, indicating that cyclohexanone was the key intermediate to generate cyclohexanol and cyclohexane. Furthermore, when using benzene as reactant, no cyclohexane was observed, whereas only cyclohexane was generated when using cyclohexanol as reactant. This control experiment suggested that a fraction of phenol could be hydrogenated to form cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol, then cyclohexanone further converted into cyclohexanol, and finally partial cyclohexanol converted into cyclohexane. The detailed pathway of the anisole hydrogenation reaction was presented in Fig. 6b, which contains the reaction process of all the side products. 3.5 Transformation of other substituted anisole To investigate the applicability of 4Ni1Al-S catalyst, the catalytic performance of different methyl substituted anisole to cresol were also evaluated, as shown in Table 3 . Different substituted position with flexible steric and electronic effects significantly influenced the conversion rate and phenol selectivity [26,46]. When the methyl substituted at ortho position, the conversion was slight lower than that of anisole while the phenol selectivity was nearly the same. When the methyl substituted at para position, both conversion and yield were distinctly decreased. As for meta-methyl anisole, the conversion only reached 46.1% for 4 h and improved to 99.8% with the reaction time prolonged to 8 h. In summary, the substitution may mainly affect the reaction rate of CAr-OCH3 cleavage, but the high selectivity towarded phenol product remain high level, which further comfired the outstanding selective demethylation ability of 4Ni1Al-S catalyst. 3.6 Reproducibility and reusability of the catalyst The reusability of 4Ni1Al-S catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of anisole was further investigated. After the reaction was completed, the catalyst was collected by simple filtration and was directly used in the next cycle. As shown in Fig. 7 a and Table S6, the anisole conversion and phenol selectivity displayed continuous dramatic decline over the fourth recycle, suggesting that the catalyst underwent significant deactivation. To clarify the deactivation reasons for the recycled 4Ni1Al-S catalyst, the XRD characterization was conducted to compare the difference between the fresh and the recycled catalysts. Fig. 7b clearly showed that the Ni9S8 and NixS6 phase in fresh catalyst translated to Ni3S2 phase after the first cycle, which agrees well with the ICP analysis listed in Table 1 which showed that the S content was decreased from 27.1 wt.% to 25.1 wt.%. It is inferred that the fresh catalysts suffered sulfur loss during the reaction and thus formed Ni3S2 with lower intrinsic activity. We further collected the gas product after the reaction and analyzed it by GC, the presence of H2S suggested that the catalyst undergoes desulfurization during the catalytic hydrogenation process. ICP analyses hardly detected Ni and S content in the solution after the first run, suggesting negligible leaching of the catalytically active specie during the reaction. Hot filtration experiment was further performed to make clear the effect of sulfur loss. When reaction was carried out for 1 h, the anisole conversion was 56.4%. After filtration, the anisole conversion was maintained at 57.1% under the same conditions for additional 1 h (Table S7). Therefore, the absence of catalytic activity in hot filtrate solution further suggests rarely active specie leaching into solution. To recover the catalytic activity of the spent catalyst, we re-sulfurized the 4th 4Ni1Al-S catalyst to regenerate the active phase. As shown in Fig. 6b, the regenerate 4th 4Ni1Al-S catalyst displayed almost the same peaks as fresh 4Ni1Al-S catalyst, indicating that the Ni3S2 phase recovered to Ni9S8 and NixS6 phase during the re-sulfidation process. The activity experiment also demonstrated that the catalytic performance was recovered in some extent. To the best of our knowledge, catalyst deactivation caused by the loss of sulfur is inevitable for sulfide-based catalysts in reactions at a temperature higher than 200 °C [22,44]. More works focusing on the improvement of stability for the metal sulfide catalyst are requisite in future research. 4 Conclusions In this work, xNiyAl-S catalyst with different Ni/Al molar ratio derived from the in situ sulfidation of NiAl-LDH was prepared and employed in the demethylation of anisole. The characterization results showed that the as-designed xNiyAl-S catalyst consisted of nickel sulfide (Ni9S8+NixS6) supported on Al2O3 matrix, and the nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure exhibited stronger metal-support interaction than that obtained from the impregnation method, which not only benefits the uniform dispersion of active nickel sulfide but also results in the electronic transfer from Ni center to Al2O3 support. In the demethylation of anisole, the 4Ni1Al-S afforded a phenol yield up to 95.6% at 270 °C under 2 Mpa H2 for 5 h, which was significantly higher than that of Ni-S/Al2O3-IM and most of the reported state-of-the-art results. The reaction pathway was further proposed based on the distribution of products at different reaction times, additional control experiments and kinetic studies. The catalytic performance of different methyl substituted anisole to cresol were also evaluated, which further demonstrated the excellent demethylation ability of the 4Ni1Al-S catalyst. The cyclic stability experiment showed that the catalytic species suffered sulfur loss with the release of H2S during the reaction and thus translated to Ni3S2 with lower intrinsic activity, and the hot filtration experiment proved that rarely active specie leaching into solution. These findings may inspire further capability on designing efficient catalytic materials for selective cleavage of C-O bond in lignin to produce value-added chemicals. coredata.dc:description: The production of phenol from lignin or its model compounds, instead of cumene oxidation is very interesting from the viewpoint of sustainability and economics. The selective demethylation of anisole was an efficient but challenging route to produce phenol. In this work, we demonstrated the fabrication of nickel sulfide (Ni9S8+NixS6) nanoparticles on Al2O3 matrix by a facile in situ sulfidation of NiAl hydrotalcite and announced that nickel sulfide can serve as efficient active site for the demethylation of anisole for the first time. The as-designed 4Ni1Al-S catalyst exhibited a hierarchical morphology with a high particle density and high dispersion, affording a 95.6% yield of phenol in the demethylation of anisole under relative milder reaction temperature (270 °C) when compared to the reported state-of-the-art results. By comprehensive characterizations and experiments, we inferred that the nickel sulfide exsolved from the LDH structure exhibited stronger metal-support interaction than that obtained from the impregnation method, which not only benefits the uniform dispersion of active nickel sulfide but also results in the electronic transfer from Ni center to Al2O3 support. As a consequence, enhanced demethylation activity was achieved on 4Ni1Al-S in comparison to Ni-S/Al2O3-IM.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced demethylation of aromatic ether to phenol over NiAl hydrotalcite-derived nickel sulfide catalyst
